results.title: Pyongyang diaries
results.brief_description: This documentary records Hoaas’ personal encounter with the closed society of North Korea (the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea). In a landscape replete with showcase monuments and bombastic images of progress, the film explores these images as a presentation of an idealised reality, and between them, forms an image of the people through observations, conversations, and personal diary reflections on other experiences at the time of filming. As with her earlier work, Hoaas approaches her film as a cumulation of fragments encompassing different perspectives that together offer a point of entry into a complex society. Her diary-style narration signals her limited personal perspective into this culture, especially given the brief filming period and her difficulty in breaking through the facade of the showcase version of Korea insisted upon by her official guides. Hoaas’ restricted visual access, and her reluctance to present over-familiar images of the hardship and depravation informed her decision to use this narrative device to frame her film within the context of the famine crisis that began in 1997 following the failure of crops caused by two consecutive years of heavy flooding. Reference: Hoaas, Solrun. ‘Pyongyang Diaries: director’s notes’ Documenter Vol. 4 No. 1 March 2001. http://www.documenter.com/back011/011hoaaa.htm

results.title: Pygmies of the Ituri Forest
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Jean-Pierre Hallet
results.brief_description: Records the many aspects of the life of the Efe Pygmies of Zaire, Africa. Pygmies cease to grow after eight - nine years but they also mature incredibly quickly and are ready for marriage at this age. Looks at thier ceremonies and rituals and at exploitation and destruction of their home forest.

results.title: Pygmies of Africa
results.brief_description: Depicts phases of pygmy life in the Congo River region of Central Africa including gathering of food, hunting methods, bartering processes, witch doctor mysticism and native superstitions.

results.title: Pygmalion
results.creator_credit: Pascal Film Productions, Gabriel Pascal, Anthony Asquith and Leslie Howard
results.brief_description: When Bernard Shaw saw this film of his play Pygmalion, he said to Wendy Hiller who plays Eliza Doolittle, “You’ve nearly wiped my old play off the map.” And you will be impressed and moved by her wonderful portrayal of one of the most famous characters in 20th century theatre. Leslie Howard who co-directed the film with Anthony Asquith, gives a fresh, witty and incisive performance as Professor Higgins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pascal Film Productions, Gabriel Pascal, Anthony Asquith and Leslie Howard

results.title: Puzzle children
results.creator_credit: WQED, Stephen Beck and Bill Davis
results.brief_description: Discusses learning disabilities in children and identifies some of the myths that prevent an accurate understanding of these problems. Profiles four children with specific learning handicaps. Including comments by their parents, teachers, and special educators. Hosted by Julie Andrews and Bill Bixby.

results.title: Putting waste to work: energy from methane
results.brief_description: In the search for energy alternatives to fossil fuels, a number of ways have been discovered to employ the methane rich gas produced from various waste materials. This video explores a number of situations where this valuable resource has been harnessed. These include a municipal land fill tip and a sewage treatment plant. Various aspects of science, technology and society are examined.

results.title: Putting the atom to work
results.brief_description: Atomic power in medicine, food preservation, and generation of electric power, future uses, and the dangers of nuclear energy. Calder Hall and Chapel Cross nuclear power stations. Britain’s first nuclear power programme consists of a number of stations. In 1962 the first of these started operating at Berkeley. A simple account of applied nuclear fission in Britain, showing the operation of nuclear power stations and production of radioactive isotopes.

results.title: Putting out the garbage
results.creator_credit: Video Projects, Tony Wright and Julie Harris
results.brief_description: Domestic violence is the most frequently occurring and under reported crime in Australia. It includes emotional, physical, sexual, financial and social abuse. This video is designed for use by women, community groups, police, schools, professional training bodies and educational organisations.

results.title: Putting on a show
results.brief_description: Sandra Power, an English migrant who has just joined a Sydney newspaper, is shown touring rural districts in New South Wales as they prepare for their annual agricultural shows.

results.title: Putting it straight: A story of crooked teeth
results.brief_description: Explains the causes of irregular teeth and the importance of systematic care of the primary teeth. Demonstrates corrective treatment.
